node.title: 'The hero of their own story': Why not a disabled Disney princess?
node.alt: Midshot of woman with dark hair wearing a pink long-sleeve blouse, sitting in a wheelchair that is not in view.
node.description: Hannah Diviney is pushing for Disney to develop a disabled princess character.
node.content:
["Hannah Diviney grew up never seeing anyone who looked like her on TV, and as she grew up that became her motivation for change.\u00a0", "Ms Diviney, now aged 22, had a love of storytelling as a child and a unique perspective born of her love for the written word and media.", "\"The main thing that I want is for disabled kids to see themselves as the heroes of their own stories and to have control over their own narratives because that doesn't happen very often, [and to] see themselves having friends, falling in love, and having adventures,\" she said.", "Now she is trying to change the way the world sees Disney animation through a petition that has gained tens of thousands of signatures and growing recognition from the likes of Hollywood actor\u00a0Reese Witherspoon.", "As Ms Diviney grew up, she continued to realise the power of storytelling and how stories shaped people.", "When she was four years old, she created a small book titled Christmas at Arndu\u00a0named after her pre-school where the book was set.", "", "
Ms Diviney never felt like she saw herself in the Disney princesses on the big screen growing up.(Supplied:\u00a0Hannah Diviney)
", "\"Even now I can remember the rush that I got when my mum was writing this story out for me as I was telling her,\" Ms Diviney said.", "\"My brain was very quick to be like, 'Oh, this is something we're very good at, let's keep going with this.' \"", "Ms Diviney wants to help change the face of popular culture and mainstream media for the next and future generations.", "\"Pretty much the only frames of reference I had for disabled people [in the media] growing up were Paralympic athletes \u2026 often used by society as models for inspiration,\" she said.", "\"On the other side you have disability being presented as the consequence of tragedy in a drink driving ad or a smoking ad \u2014\u00a0something where it becomes very clear that the life-altering thing means that life is 'over'.\"", "The Wollongong University graduate disliked the negative message that living with a disability was \"damaging\" and \"tricky\" to navigate.", "", "
As Ms Diviney grew up, she continued to realise the power of storytelling and how it shapes people.\u00a0(Supplied: Hannah Diviney)
", "In December 2020, these experiences from growing up resulted in Ms Diviney starting a petition for Disney to create a princess with a disability.", "She has always been a fan of Disney films but \"has never seen herself in them\".", "At the time of writing, the petition had more than 55,000 signatures.", "\"What we need is decision-makers in LA\u00a0to take notice,\" Ms Diviney said.", "\"Apparently Disney Australia and New Zealand know who I am\u00a0but no-one has ever reached out to me.\"", "Her campaign to create a princess with a disability\u00a0has grown and attracted the support of famous figures from around the world\u00a0including author Neil Gaiman\u00a0and actors Reese Witherspoon, Jameela Jamil, and Mark Hamill.", "Reese Witherspoon's media company Hello Sunshine featured her on the 2021 International Day of the Girl, highlighting her work with the Missing Perspectives team.", "Ms Diviney has herself started to conceptualise a Disney princess called Stella, named for Stella Young, who was an Australian disability rights activist.", "When she is not busy with advocacy work, Ms Diviney is rewriting the narrative herself.", "In 2015, she was the youngest person to work at news website\u00a0Mamamia and is now the co-editor in chief and head of creative for Missing Perspectives \u2014\u00a0an online platform telling the stories of young women around the world and addressing the media's depiction of them.", "ABC is partnering with International Day of People with Disability to celebrate the contributions and achievements of the 4.4 million Australians with disability."]
